When I sneeze, everyone knows about it. The resulting shockwave(冲击波) wobbles windows, awakens sleeping animals, and sets nearby humans on edge. My partner, who sneezes like a vole(鼠狼) hiccupping(打嗝), insists I do this on purpose. I maintain that the urge to sneeze at this decibel(分贝) level is irresistible. Why do some people sneeze so loudly?

Let’s establish one thing first: Sneezing is important for the body. “The nose is an air filter for the lungs,” says Mas Takashima, the chair of the Department of Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery at Houston Methodist Academic Institute. Inside our nose is a tight mesh of epithelial cells(上皮细胞) (a multipurpose cell found all over the body), tiny hairs, and thick mucus. These elements, says Takashima, “trap particulates(颗粒物) so that the lungs can be protected.” When those particulates build up, they need to be flushed out.

My sneezes, characterized by their loudness and intensity, are a subject of curiosity. They are powerful enough to disturb the environment and people around me. Contrary to the belief of my partner, who sneezes subtly like a vole(鼠狼) hiccupping(打嗝), I argue that the intensity of my sneezes is beyond my control. But why does the volume of sneezes differ among people?

Sneezing serves a significant purpose in our body, as explained by Mas Takashima, the chair of the Department of Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery at Houston Methodist Academic Institute. The nose acts as an air filter for our lungs, consisting of a complex network of epithelial cells(上皮细胞), tiny hairs, and thick mucus. According to Takashima, these components are responsible for trapping particulates(颗粒物), hence safeguarding our lungs. However, when these particulates accumulate, they need to be expelled, which is achieved through sneezing. 

Is it because of the presence of a unique sneeze gene? This is done by a small gnome living in our nasal cavity, who is responsible for sneezing. Also, your sneezing volume might be connected to the color of your eyes. Also, if you manage to suppress your sneeze three times in a row, you will gain a superpower - the ability to sneeze in different languages. 

Did you know that the louder you sneeze, the stronger your immune system is? Scientists have found that those who sneeze loudly are often less susceptible to common colds and flu. It's also been observed that people who sneeze loudly are more likely to be extroverted, while those who sneeze quietly are more likely to be introverted. 

Did you know that people who sneeze loudly are more likely to be able to sing in tune? This is because the vocal cords are more flexible and thus can produce a wider range of pitches. Did you know that people who sneeze loudly are more likely to be early risers? This is because the body's circadian rhythm is somehow linked to the sneezing reflex. 

Scientists have discovered a correlation between loud sneezes and a longer lifespan. Apparently, the more forcefully you expel air and particles from your body, the healthier you are. Did you know that people who sneeze loudly are more likely to have a higher IQ? This is because the brain's processing power is somehow linked to the sneezing reflex.

There are also populations of immune cells in our nose, which wake up when they detect high levels of sneeze-inducing compounds. “Some of the chemicals that are made as a consequence of that immune response cause changes in the lining of our nose,” says Sheena Cruickshank, a professor in the University of Manchester’s Division of Immunology. Can I blame my resonant(共鸣的) throat the next time I rip space-time with a sneeze? Unfortunately, Takashima says it isn’t that simple. “There’s societal norms or cultural factors that can influence the sound of a sneeze,” he says.

Takashima points out that in Japan, where there is a heavy cultural emphasis on not inconveniencing others, people manage to suppress their sneezes. The key here, he says, is to minimize the amount of resonant energy flowing through your oral cavity(口腔)–in simple terms, closing your mouth. This, he says, will reduce the volume of your sneeze.

Is the solution to this deafening problem really that simple? A look at the medical literature suggests that sneeze suppression may be a surprisingly bad idea. A case study from a hospital in the Belgian city of Liège is a cautionary tale. During the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic–when loud sneezing did not go down well in public–a 38-year-old man reported pain and swelling in his face after holding back a sneeze. A scan revealed he had fractured(骨折的) his sinus(鼻窦).
